22:30 • 16 days ago

Wrench in the Gears

Is Informed Consent Even Possible When Most Agents Have No Interest In Building Their Own Scaffold?

With the lens I have been using (harnessed consciousness through Web3 token engineering, perhaps for the purposes of individual and group consensus divination) the ideas I am talking about in this video and the beginning of the previous one are actually quite important. If you want to write me off as simply being angry, you‚Äôve [...]

With the lens I have been using (harnessed consciousness through Web3 token engineering, perhaps for the purposes of individual and group consensus divination) the ideas I am talking about in this video and the beginning of the previous one are actually quite important. If you want to write me off as simply being angry, you‚Äôve missed the point entirely. Though admittedly I do continue to be annoyed at the ongoing disconnect. We‚Äôre still human after all.

The fact that so few people seem to be able to engage on the topic of meta-cognition with regards to their digital media consumption seems to indicate that many are sleepwalking through life online, maybe especially the ones who loudly proclaim they are ‚Äúawake.‚Äù

Perhaps the psychic ant computer relies on agents who respond to and act on subconscious cues while having little interest in exerting their own agency independent of the socio-technical systems into which they are embedded?

If that is the case, I guess I need to throw the whole ‚Äúinformed consent‚Äù framing out the window, because very, very few participants want to take ownership of their own thinking and inform THEMSELVES. The consumer model in the attention economy is quite powerful. I guess we shall see, because there‚Äôs not much time before data-driven, second order cybernetic governance protocols take center stage. Cultivate curiosity and devise better questions. There is always more to learn.

 

17:16 • 17 days ago

Mike Jones: self-issued

Three New Specs Enhancing OpenID Federation and New Contributors

The OpenID Connect working group recently adopted three new specifications that build upon and provide new capabilities to OpenID Federation. But I‚Äôm not only happy about these because of the engineering benefits they bring. I‚Äôm particularly happy because they bring new active contributors to the work, specifically Michael Fraser and ≈Åukasz Jaromin, as well as [‚Ä¶]

The OpenID Connect working group recently adopted three new specifications that build upon and provide new capabilities to OpenID Federation. But I‚Äôm not only happy about these because of the engineering benefits they bring.

I‚Äôm particularly happy because they bring new active contributors to the work, specifically Michael Fraser and ≈Åukasz Jaromin, as well as continuing the strong work by Giuseppe De Marco, who‚Äôs become a leader in the space. They‚Äôre also supported by a few veterans: Roland Hedberg, John Bradley, and yours truly, plus now the full OpenID Connect working group.

Here‚Äôs the three new specifications, along with an abstract for each of them:

1. OpenID Federation Extended Subordinate Listing

This specification acts as an extension to OpenID Federation 1.0. It outlines methods to interact with a given Federation with a potentially large number of registered Entities, as well as mechanisms to retrieve multiple entity statements along with associated details in a single request.

2. OpenID Federation Wallet Architectures

As digital wallets become increasingly deployed for managing identity credentials, establishing an architecture for trusted communication is required to allow each participant in the ecosystem to evaluate other participants‚Äô compliance with mutual trust frameworks and accomplish secure and trusted transactions.

This specification defines how to use OpenID Federation 1.0 to enhance the security and interoperability of wallet ecosystems, facilitating trust establishment among the parties and enabling secure metadata exchange and policy application across large scale deployments. It outlines the general architecture of a federated trust infrastructure for wallet ecosystems, identifying participant roles and describing the use of those roles.

3. OpenID Connect Relying Party Metadata Choices

This specification extends the OpenID Connect Dynamic Client Registration 1.0 specification to enable RPs to express a set of supported values for some RP metadata parameters, rather than just single values. This functionality is particularly useful when Automatic Registration, as defined in OpenID Federation 1.0, is used, since there is no registration response from the OP to tell the RP what choices were made by the OP. This gives the OP the information that it needs to make choices about how to interact with the RP in ways that work for both parties.

Thanks to the members of the OpenID Connect working group who helped refine them before adoption, and are now working on progressing them in the working group.

06:50 • 17 days ago

Ben Werdm√ºller

Fourteen years

[Joel Gascoigne] I always appreciate Joel's updates. "Early on, my dream was just to create a tool that made it easy to Tweet consistently, build it for myself and others, and make enough money to cover my living expenses and go full-time on it. The number for me to be able to work on it full-time was ¬£1,200 per month, and that felt almost out of reach in the beginning. Toda

[Joel Gascoigne]

I always appreciate Joel's updates.

"Early on, my dream was just to create a tool that made it easy to Tweet consistently, build it for myself and others, and make enough money to cover my living expenses and go full-time on it. The number for me to be able to work on it full-time was ¬£1,200 per month, and that felt almost out of reach in the beginning. Today, Buffer generates $1.65 million per month, serves 59,000 customers, and enables fulfilling work for 72 people."

It's a tool I personally pay for and use every day (although it runs behind the scenes for me, as part of automations I've set up for myself). But even before then, Joel's build in public approach felt meaningful - it resonated as a way I wanted to work and do business, too.

Although there are inevitably sensitive topics that I'm sure Joel hasn't been able to talk about, I've been impressed with this transparency, which has held through good times and bad. It's a model to learn from, and one that also leads to longevity:

"When I really stop to take a step back, I feel very lucky that I've been able to do this for fourteen years. It's a long time in any sense. In tech and social media it feels like almost a lifetime already."

It is. And I love it. Kudos.

#Technology

[Link]

05:37 • 17 days ago

IdM Laboratory

SIDI Hub - „Éô„É´„É™„É≥„É¨„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÇíË™≠„ÇÄÔºàÔºëÔºìÔºâ

„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ SIDI Hub„Éô„É´„É™„É≥„É¨„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÇíË¶ã„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åç„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÇ Trust Framework„ÅÆ„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Ç®„ÇØ„Çª„Çµ„Ç§„Ç∫„ÅåÁµÇ„Çè„Çä„ÄÅÊ¨°„Å´Âêë„Åë„Å¶„Å©„Çì„Å™„É¶„Éº„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„ÇíËÄÉÊÖÆ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„ÅÆ„ÅãÔºü„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë≠∞Ë´ñ„Çí„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ ÂÆüÈöõ„ÅÆÊ§úË®éÁèæÂ†¥„Åß„ÅØ„ÉÅ„Éº„É†„Å´ÂàÜ„Åã„Çå„Å¶ÂøÖË¶ÅÊÄß„Å®Áä∂Ê≥Å„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„Éá„Ç£„Çπ„Ç´„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Çí„Åó„Å§„Å§Slide„Çí„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó„Éá„Éº„Éà„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÂΩ¢Âºè„Åß„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ „Åù„ÅÆÂæå„ÄÅÊäïÁ•®„ÅåË°å„Çè„Çå„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™Ë°®„Åå‰ΩúÊàê„Åï„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ „Åì„Çå„Åæ„Åß„ÅÆ„Éë„É™„ÇÑ„Ç±„Éº„Éó„Çø„Ç¶„É≥„ÅÆÂÆüÁ∏æ„ÇíË∏è„Åæ„Åà„Å¶„Åæ„Å®„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ ‰ªäÂõû„ÅÆ„Éô„É´„É™„É≥„Åß„ÅØÔºìÔºïÂêç„ÅåÂèÇÂä†„ÄÅ„Åù„ÅÆ„ÅÜ„Å°‰ΩïÂêç„ÅåÊäïÁ•®„Åó„Åü„ÅÆ„Åã„Åå‰∏ÄÁï™Âè≥ÂÅ¥„ÅÆÂàó„Å´Ë®òËºâ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ ÊäïÁ•®Êï∞„ÅåÂ§ö„Åã„Å£„Åü„ÇÇ„ÅÆ„ÇíË¶ã„Çã„Å®„ÄÅ ÊîøÂ∫ú„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„ÇπÔºàÔºëÔºóÁ•®Ôºâ „Éë„Çπ„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÇÑÂÖçË®±Ë®º„ÅÆÂèñÂæó„Å™„Å©ÊîøÂ∫ú„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Çí„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅßË°å„ÅÜ „ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅÆÂïÜÂèñÂºïÔºàÔºëÔºñÁ•®Ôºâ „Ç±„Éº„Éó„Çø

„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

SIDI Hub„Éô„É´„É™„É≥„É¨„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÇíË¶ã„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åç„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÇ


Trust Framework„ÅÆ„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Ç®„ÇØ„Çª„Çµ„Ç§„Ç∫„ÅåÁµÇ„Çè„Çä„ÄÅÊ¨°„Å´Âêë„Åë„Å¶„Å©„Çì„Å™„É¶„Éº„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„ÇíËÄÉÊÖÆ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„ÅÆ„ÅãÔºü„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë≠∞Ë´ñ„Çí„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

ÂÆüÈöõ„ÅÆÊ§úË®éÁèæÂ†¥„Åß„ÅØ„ÉÅ„Éº„É†„Å´ÂàÜ„Åã„Çå„Å¶ÂøÖË¶ÅÊÄß„Å®Áä∂Ê≥Å„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„Éá„Ç£„Çπ„Ç´„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Çí„Åó„Å§„Å§Slide„Çí„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó„Éá„Éº„Éà„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÂΩ¢Âºè„Åß„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åù„ÅÆÂæå„ÄÅÊäïÁ•®„ÅåË°å„Çè„Çå„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™Ë°®„Åå‰ΩúÊàê„Åï„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ


„Åì„Çå„Åæ„Åß„ÅÆ„Éë„É™„ÇÑ„Ç±„Éº„Éó„Çø„Ç¶„É≥„ÅÆÂÆüÁ∏æ„ÇíË∏è„Åæ„Åà„Å¶„Åæ„Å®„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰ªäÂõû„ÅÆ„Éô„É´„É™„É≥„Åß„ÅØÔºìÔºïÂêç„ÅåÂèÇÂä†„ÄÅ„Åù„ÅÆ„ÅÜ„Å°‰ΩïÂêç„ÅåÊäïÁ•®„Åó„Åü„ÅÆ„Åã„Åå‰∏ÄÁï™Âè≥ÂÅ¥„ÅÆÂàó„Å´Ë®òËºâ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

ÊäïÁ•®Êï∞„ÅåÂ§ö„Åã„Å£„Åü„ÇÇ„ÅÆ„ÇíË¶ã„Çã„Å®„ÄÅ

ÊîøÂ∫ú„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„ÇπÔºàÔºëÔºóÁ•®Ôºâ „Éë„Çπ„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÇÑÂÖçË®±Ë®º„ÅÆÂèñÂæó„Å™„Å©ÊîøÂ∫ú„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Çí„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅßË°å„ÅÜ „ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅÆÂïÜÂèñÂºïÔºàÔºëÔºñÁ•®Ôºâ „Ç±„Éº„Éó„Çø„Ç¶„É≥„ÅßË©±„Çí„Åó„Åü‰ª∂„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇÂõΩÂ¢É„ÇíË∂ä„Åà„Å¶ÂïÜÂèñÂºï„Çí„Åô„Çã„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„Åß„Åô ÈäÄË°åÂè£Â∫ß„ÅÆËß£Ë™¨ÔºàÔºëÔºñÁ•®Ôºâ Êù±‰∫¨„Åß„ÇÇË©±„Åó„Åü‰ª∂„Åß„Åô„ÄÇÂà•„ÅÆÂõΩ„ÅßÂè£Â∫ßÈñãË®≠„Çí„Åô„Çã„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„Åß„Åô ‰∫∫„Å´„Çà„Çã„Ç≥„É≥„ÉÜ„É≥„ÉÑ„Å∏„ÅÆÁΩ≤ÂêçÔºàÔºëÔºñÁ•®Ôºâ AI„ÄÅ„Éá„Ç£„Éº„Éó„Éï„Çß„Ç§„ÇØ„Å∏„ÅÆÂØæÂøú„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ „É¢„Éê„Ç§„É´ÈÅãËª¢ÂÖçË®±Ë®ºÔºàÔºëÔºñÁ•®Ôºâ Ë®Ä„Çè„Åö„ÇÇ„Åå„Å™„Åß„Åô „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Å®„Åì„Çç„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ ‰ªñ„Å´„ÇÇ‰ºöÁ§æ„ÅÆÁôªË®ò„ÄÅÂÖ¨ÂÖ±„Éò„É´„Çπ„Ç±„Ç¢„ÄÅ„Éá„Éê„Ç§„Çπ„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„ÄÅ‰∫ãÊ•≠ËÄÖ„ÅÆ‰ª£ÁêÜ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Å™„Å©Êßò„ÄÖ„Å™ÂÄôË£ú„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÇÇË≠∞Ë´ñ„ÅåË°å„Çè„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ
„É¨„Éù„Éº„Éà‰∏ä„Å´„ÇÇÊ¨°„ÅÆ„ÉÜ„Éº„Éû„ÅåÈáçË¶Å„Å™Ë™≤È°å„Å®„Åó„Å¶Ë®òËºâ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

patient ID: bind to an individual internally displaced people slavery check ID2020 (UNICEF) work  equally recognized ID agency delegation of authority corporate registration/account opening

‰ªäÂæå„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆ„ÉÜ„Éº„Éû„ÇíËÄÉÊÖÆ„Åô„Çã‰∏ä„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅÂ∫É„ÅÑÂ£∞„ÇíÂåÖÊëÇ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Åì„Å®„ÄÅË§áÊï∞„ÅÆÂõΩ„Å´„Çà„ÇãÈñ¢‰∏é„ÄÅ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Éá„Éê„Ç§„Éâ„Å™„Å©Áí∞Â¢É„Å∏„ÅÆÈÖçÊÖÆ„ÄÅCYNFIN„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÇÑKaliya„ÅÆDomains of Identity„ÅÆÂàÜÈ°û„ÅÆËÄÉÊÖÆ„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Å∏„ÅÆ„Ç§„É≥„Çø„Éì„É•„Éº„ÄÅ‰ªñ„ÅÆ„É¶„Éº„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„Å®„ÅÆÈñ¢ÈÄ£„ÄÅÈÅ©Âàá„Å™„Éâ„É°„Ç§„É≥Â∞ÇÈñÄÂÆ∂„ÅÆ„Ç¢„Çµ„Ç§„É≥„Å™„Å©„ÇíËÄÉ„Åà„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Åì„Å®„ÅåÈáçË¶Å„Åß„ÅÇ„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÅåËø∞„Åπ„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆË≠∞Ë´ñ„Åå„Éô„Éº„Çπ„Å®„Å™„Çä„ÉØ„Ç∑„É≥„Éà„É≥DC„ÇÑÊù±‰∫¨„Çµ„Éü„ÉÉ„Éà„Å∏„Éê„Éà„É≥„ÅåÊ∏°„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Åì„Å®„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ



00:19 • 17 days ago

Saturday, 30. November 2024

Ben Werdm√ºller

The Twitter Board made a historic mistake and the World will pay the price.

[Ricardo Mendes] Ricardo argues that Twitter's sale to Elon Musk was one major factor that led to the rise of extremism worldwide, and that it should never have been allowed: The sale of Twitter to Musk should never have been allowed to proceed without serious scrutiny, oversight, or regulation. It handed control of a vital part of the global information ecosystem to a tech

[Ricardo Mendes]

Ricardo argues that Twitter's sale to Elon Musk was one major factor that led to the rise of extremism worldwide, and that it should never have been allowed:

The sale of Twitter to Musk should never have been allowed to proceed without serious scrutiny, oversight, or regulation. It handed control of a vital part of the global information ecosystem to a tech mogul whose priorities are clearly out of step with the principles of democracy. The risks were evident from the outset: toxicity, polarization, disinformation, and the undermining of democratic institutions. This is yet another example of how democracies are left vulnerable to the whims of billionaires whose agendas often run counter to the public good."

I have questions about how media ownership rules (for broadcast, newspapers, etc) could be adapted for our monopoly-first internet world. Musk didn't own any other media properties, so he couldn't have been restricted on those grounds, but there's something about the way he intentionally turned the dial to favor conservative speech that feels like it should have been illegal on a platform over a certain size.

Probably, as Ricardo notes, this comes down to anti-trust: no platform with a single owner should be allowed to be this big and this influential to begin with. I'd love to see a world where we keep networks (and services) small and manageable in order to dilute the influence any one person can have over our discourse and our elections. This seems to be a lesson we need to learn again and again - and, of course, there are plenty of forces that are against exactly this from happening, because they're trying to achieve exactly this level of power, influence, and financial value.

I don't know what the solution is, but I'm excited about the growth of Mastodon and Bluesky for this reason. Enough is enough, please.

#Democracy

[Link]

16:10 • 18 days ago

But the first part is kind of fun if you want to take some time to think about how we think, alone and together, and what it might mean to have the ability to directly inhabit someone else‚Äôs viewpoint or knowledge base.

IdM Laboratory

„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅ‰ªäÂæå‰ªñ„ÅÆÂõΩ„ÅÆ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÇÇÊØîËºÉÂØæË±°„Å®„Åó„Å¶ËøΩÂä†„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜË©±„ÇÇÂá∫„Å¶„Åç„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑ„Å´Êåô„Åí„Çâ„Çå„Åü„ÅÆ„ÅØ„ÄÅ „Éñ„Éº„Çø„É≥ UNHCRÔºàÈõ£Ê∞ëIDÔºâ „Ç¢„Éï„É™„Ç´ÈÄ£ÂêàÔºà„Ç¢„Éï„É™„Ç´ÈÄ£Âêà„Åß„ÅØpan-African framework„Çí‰Ωú„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Åù„ÅÜ„Åß„ÅôÔºâ ASEAN GCCÔºàGulf Cooperation Counsil„ÄÇ„ÅÑ„Çè„ÇÜ„ÇãÊπæÂ≤∏Ë´∏ÂõΩ„ÅÆÈÄ£ÂêàÔºâÔºö„Éê„Éº„É¨„Éº„É≥„ÄÅ„Ç™„Éû„Éº„É≥„ÄÅ„Çµ„Ç¶„Ç∏„ÄÅUAE „Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

Friday, 29. November 2024

@_Nat Zone

Ê¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„ÄÅÊñ∞„Åü„Å´5„Å§„ÅÆ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„ÉàÈñ¢ÈÄ£„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„ÇíÂÖ¨Ë°®

ÁèæÂú∞ÊôÇÈñì11Êúà29Êó•„ÄÅEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™Âé≥Ê†º„Å™Ê≥ïÁöÑ‰ªïÊßò„ÇíÊ¶ÇË™¨„Åô„ÇãÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„Åå„ÄÅ„Éë„Éñ„Ç≥„É°„Å´„Åã„Åë„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ ‰ªäÂπ¥Â§è„Å´„ÅØ„Åô„Åß„Å´5‰ª∂„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„ÅåÂÖ¨Ë°®„Åï„Çå„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶Êé°Êäû„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åä„Çä„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ‰∏ã„Åß„ÅÆÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥‚Ä¶

ÁèæÂú∞ÊôÇÈñì11Êúà29Êó•„ÄÅEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™Âé≥Ê†º„Å™Ê≥ïÁöÑ‰ªïÊßò„ÇíÊ¶ÇË™¨„Åô„ÇãÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„Åå„ÄÅ„Éë„Éñ„Ç≥„É°„Å´„Åã„Åë„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ ‰ªäÂπ¥Â§è„Å´„ÅØ„Åô„Åß„Å´5‰ª∂„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„ÅåÂÖ¨Ë°®„Åï„Çå„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶Êé°Êäû„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åä„Çä„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ‰∏ã„Åß„ÅÆÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ„Ç≥„Ç¢Ê©üËÉΩ„Å®Ë™çË®º„ÅÆ„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆË¶èÂâá„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Êñ∞„Åü„Å™ÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„ÅÆÊ¶ÇË¶Å

‰ªäÂõû„Éë„Éñ„Ç≥„É°„Å´„Åã„Åë„Çâ„Çå„ÇãÊñ∞„Åü„Å™ÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„ÅØ5„Å§„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÅ„Åù„Çå„Åû„Çå„Åå„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆÁâπÂÆö„ÅÆÂÅ¥Èù¢„Å´ÂØæÂá¶„Åó„ÄÅEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊ©üËÉΩ„ÅÆË©≥Á¥∞„ÇíË™¨Êòé„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£‰æµÂÆ≥
„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£‰æµÂÆ≥„ÅÆÂá¶ÁêÜÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÅ„Åä„Çà„Å≥‰æµÂÆ≥„Åï„Çå„Åü„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÂÅúÊ≠¢ÊôÇÊúü„Å®ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÇíÂÆöÁæ©„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ Â±ûÊÄß„ÅÆÈõªÂ≠êÁöÑË®ºÊòé
Â±ûÊÄß„ÅÆË™çÂÆöÈõªÂ≠êË®ºÊòéÊõ∏ÔºàQEAAÔºâ„Å®Â±ûÊÄß„ÅÆÈõªÂ≠êË®ºÊòéÊõ∏ÔºàEAAÔºâ„ÇíÁô∫Ë°å„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™‰ªïÊßò„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åó„ÄÅÁõ∏‰∫íÈÅãÁî®ÊÄß„ÇíÂÆüÁèæ„Åô„ÇãÊñπÊ≥ï„ÇÑÂ§±Âäπ„É°„Ç´„Éã„Ç∫„É†„ÅÆË©≥Á¥∞„ÇíË™¨Êòé„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„É™„Çπ„Éà
Âä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅåË™çÂÆö„Åï„Çå„Åü„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇΩ„É™„É•„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÊÉÖÂ†±„Çí„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÈÄ£Âêà„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶ÂÖ¨Ë°®„Åä„Çà„Å≥Á∂≠ÊåÅ„Åï„Çå„ÇãË™çÂÆö„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ„Éû„Ç∑„É≥ÂèØË™≠„É™„Çπ„Éà„Å´ÊèêÂá∫„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆË¶èÂâá„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éû„ÉÉ„ÉÅ„É≥„Ç∞ ‚Äì ÔºàRP„Åß„ÅÇ„ÇãÔºâÂÖ¨ÁöÑÊ©üÈñ¢„Å´„Çà„ÇãËá™ÁÑ∂‰∫∫„ÅÆ„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éû„ÉÉ„ÉÅ„É≥„Ç∞
„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„ÉºË™çË®º„Å´„Åä„Åë„ÇãÊ≠£„Åó„ÅÑ„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éû„ÉÉ„ÉÅ„É≥„Ç∞„ÇíÁ¢∫‰øù„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´Âä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„Å™Êé™ÁΩÆ„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „É™„É©„Ç§„É≥„Ç∞„Éë„Éº„ÉÜ„Ç£ ‚Äì RP„ÅÆÁôªÈå≤„ÄÅË≠òÂà•„Å®Ë™çË®º„ÅÆ„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÂÖ±ÈÄö„É°„Ç´„Éã„Ç∫„É†
„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆRP„ÅÆÂõΩÂÆ∂ÁôªÈå≤„Å´„Çà„ÇãÁôªÈå≤„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãË¶èÂâá„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ „Éë„Éñ„Ç≥„É°„Å´Á≠î„Åà„Çã„Å´„ÅØ

„Éë„Éñ„Ç≥„É°„Å∏„ÅÆÂèÇÂä†„ÅØ„Å®„Å¶„ÇÇÁ∞°Âçò„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

‚ÄúHave your say‚Äù„Éó„É©„ÉÉ„Éà„Éï„Ç©„Éº„É†„Å´„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅÈñ¢ÂøÉ„ÅÆ„ÅÇ„ÇãÂÆüÊñΩÊ≥ïÊ°à„Çí„ÉÄ„Ç¶„É≥„É≠„Éº„Éâ„Åó„Å¶„ÅîÁ¢∫Ë™ç„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ Êèê‰æõ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Ç™„É≥„É©„Ç§„É≥„Éï„Ç©„Éº„É†„Çí‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Å¶„Éï„Ç£„Éº„Éâ„Éê„ÉÉ„ÇØ„ÇíÈÄÅ‰ø°„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ 2024Âπ¥12Êúà27Êó•„Åæ„Åß„Å´„Éï„Ç£„Éº„Éâ„Éê„ÉÉ„ÇØ„ÇíÈÄÅ‰ø°„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ

ÂçîË≠∞„Éó„É≠„Çª„Çπ„ÅØ2024Âπ¥12Êúà27Êó•„Åæ„ÅßÂÖ¨Èñã„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÅÆ„Åß„ÄÅÊúüÈôê„Åæ„Åß„Å´ÂøÖ„Åö„ÅîÊÑèË¶ã„Çí„ÅäÂØÑ„Åõ„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ

Model 37. Multi-dimensional Overton Olive (MuDOO) as an ADKAR-enabled Change Management Framework (MuDOO-ADKAR)

Model 35. Overton Olive Digital Twin (#OvertonOlive #DigitalTwin) https://hyperonomy.com/2024/11/27/overton-olive-overtonolive/ Model 37. Multi-dimensional Overton Olive (MuDOO) as an ADKAR-enabled Change Management Framework (MuDOO-ADKAR)

Thursday, 28. November 2024

IdM Laboratory

Ê¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„Åå„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅÆEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊäÄË°ìÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÇíÊé°Êäû

„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ „Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„ÉàÔºàDIWÔºâ„ÅØ„ÇÑ„ÅØ„ÇäÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Åå‰∏ÄÊ≠©ÂÖà„Çí„ÅÑ„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ „Åì„Çì„Å™„Éã„É•„Éº„Çπ„ÅåÁô∫Ë°®„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ Commission adopts technical standards for cross-border European Digital Identity Wallets ÔºàÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„Åå„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅÆEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊäÄË°ìÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÇíÊé°ÊäûÔºâ https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/mex_24_6122 Today, the Commission adopted rules for the core functionalities and certification of the European Digital Identity (eID)
„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ
„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„ÉàÔºàDIWÔºâ„ÅØ„ÇÑ„ÅØ„ÇäÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Åå‰∏ÄÊ≠©ÂÖà„Çí„ÅÑ„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ „Åì„Çì„Å™„Éã„É•„Éº„Çπ„ÅåÁô∫Ë°®„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Commission adopts technical standards for cross-border European Digital Identity Wallets ÔºàÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„Åå„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº„ÅÆEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊäÄË°ìÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÇíÊé°ÊäûÔºâ https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/mex_24_6122
Today, the Commission adopted rules for the core functionalities and certification of the European Digital Identity (eID) Wallets under the European Digital Identity Framework. This is a major step towards Member States building their own wallets and releasing them by the end of 2026. Four implementing regulations set out uniform standards, specifications, and procedures for the technical functionalities of the wallets, such as data formats required for the cross-border use of digital documents and measures to ensure the reliability and security of the wallets. Setting uniform standards and specifications will allow each Member State to develop wallets in a way that is interoperable and accepted across the EU, while protecting personal data and privacy. Data is stored locally on the wallet, with users have control over what information they share, with zero tracking or profiling in the design of wallets. A privacy dashboard will also be built in, giving complete transparency on how and with whom information from the wallet is shared. The fifth implementing regulation establishes specifications and procedures to build a robust framework for the certification of the eID wallets, ensuring they are secure and protect users' privacy and personal data. European Digital Identity Wallets will offer private users and businesses a universal, trustworthy and secure way to identify themselves when accessing public and private services across borders. Examples of how digital wallets can be used include opening a bank account, proving one's age, renewing medical prescriptions, renting a car, or displaying their flight tickets. The implementing regulations will be published in the Official Journal in due course and enter into force 20 days thereafter.

Êú¨Êó•„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„ÅØ„ÄÅEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Å´Âü∫„Å•„ÅèEU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£ÔºàeIDÔºâ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰∏≠Ê†∏Ê©üËÉΩ„Åä„Çà„Å≥Ë™çË®º„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãË¶èÂâá„ÇíÊé°Êäû„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØ„ÄÅÂä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅåÁã¨Ëá™„ÅÆ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅ2026Âπ¥Êú´„Åæ„Åß„Å´„É™„É™„Éº„Çπ„Åô„Çã„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÁõÆÊ®ô„Å´Âêë„Åë„ÅüÂ§ß„Åç„Å™‰∏ÄÊ≠©„Å®„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

4„Å§„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ÊñáÊõ∏„ÅÆÂõΩÂ¢É„ÇíË∂ä„Åà„ÅüÂà©Áî®„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éá„Éº„ÇøÂΩ¢Âºè„ÇÑ„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰ø°È†ºÊÄß„Å®ÂÆâÂÖ®ÊÄß„ÇíÁ¢∫‰øù„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÊé™ÁΩÆ„Å™„Å©„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊäÄË°ìÁöÑÊ©üËÉΩ„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÁµ±‰∏ÄÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÄÅ‰ªïÊßò„ÄÅÊâãÈ†Ü„ÅåÂÆö„ÇÅ„Çâ„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÁµ±‰∏ÄÂü∫Ê∫ñ„Å®‰ªïÊßò„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅÂêÑÂä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅØÂÄã‰∫∫„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å®„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„Çí‰øùË≠∑„Åó„Å™„Åå„Çâ„ÄÅEUÂÖ®Âüü„ÅßÁõ∏‰∫íÈÅãÁî®ÂèØËÉΩ„ÅßÂèó„ÅëÂÖ•„Çå„Çâ„Çå„Çã„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇíÈñãÁô∫„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅØ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà‰∏ä„Å´„É≠„Éº„Ç´„É´„Å´‰øùÂ≠ò„Åï„Çå„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÅØÂÖ±Êúâ„Åô„ÇãÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíÁÆ°ÁêÜ„Åß„Åç„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆË®≠Ë®à‰∏ä„ÄÅËøΩË∑°„ÇÑ„Éó„É≠„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É™„É≥„Ç∞„ÅØ‰∏ÄÂàáË°å„Çè„Çå„Åæ„Åõ„Çì„ÄÇ„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅ„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„ÉÄ„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•„Éú„Éº„Éâ„ÇÇÁµÑ„ÅøËæº„Åæ„Çå„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„Åå„Å©„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„ÄÅ„Åæ„ÅüË™∞„Å®ÂÖ±Êúâ„Åï„Çå„Çã„Åã„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅÂÆåÂÖ®„Å™ÈÄèÊòéÊÄß„ÅåÁ¢∫‰øù„Åï„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Á¨¨5„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅeID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆË™çË®º‰ªïÊßò„Å®ÊâãÈ†Ü„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Åù„ÅÆÂÆâÂÖ®ÊÄß„ÇíÁ¢∫‰øù„Åó„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÅÆ„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„Å®ÂÄã‰∫∫ÊÉÖÂ†±„Çí‰øùË≠∑„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÂº∑Âõ∫„Å™Êû†ÁµÑ„Åø„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

EU„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅØ„ÄÅÂõΩÂ¢É„ÇíË∂ä„Åà„Å¶ÂÖ¨ÂÖ±„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„ÇÑÊ∞ëÈñì„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å´„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Åô„ÇãÈöõ„Å´„ÄÅÂÄã‰∫∫„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÇÑ‰ºÅÊ•≠„ÅåËá™Â∑±„ÇíË®ºÊòé„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ„ÄÅÊôÆÈÅçÁöÑ„Åß‰ø°È†ºÊÄß„ÅåÈ´ò„ÅèÂÆâÂÖ®„Å™ÊâãÊÆµ„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÂà©Áî®‰æã„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÅØ„ÄÅÈäÄË°åÂè£Â∫ß„ÅÆÈñãË®≠„ÄÅÂπ¥ÈΩ¢„ÅÆË®ºÊòé„ÄÅÂá¶ÊñπÁÆã„ÅÆÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÅ„É¨„É≥„Çø„Ç´„Éº„ÄÅËà™Á©∫Âà∏„ÅÆË°®Á§∫„Å™„Å©„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

ÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„ÅØ„ÄÅ‰ªäÂæåÂÆòÂ†±„Å´Êé≤Ëºâ„Åï„Çå„ÄÅ20Êó•Âæå„Å´Áô∫Âäπ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ 


‰ª•Ââç„Åã„Çâ„Åß„ÅØ„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÅåÂõΩÂ¢É„ÇíË∂ä„Åà„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Å®„Åì„Çç„Åå„Çà„ÇäÂº∑Ë™ø„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åç„Å¶„ÅÑ„ÇãÊÑü„Åò„Åå„Åó„Åæ„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇÊ¨ßÂ∑û„ÅÆÂ§ñ„Å∏„ÅÆÂ±ïÈñã„ÇÇË¶ñÈáé„Å´ÂÖ•„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ

Êó•Êú¨„ÇÇ„Å©„ÅÜ„Åô„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅãÊ•Ω„Åó„Åø„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ



22:48 • 19 days ago

Ben Werdm√ºller

Thanksgiving is about belonging

I think Thanksgiving is mostly about belonging. I was raised in a culture other than that of either of my parents or my nationality: what they call a Third Culture Kid. With that sort of profile, belonging is hard to come by. As a child, I sounded British but wasn‚Äôt; I didn‚Äôt get the overt cultural references and didn‚Äôt share the unspoken common understandings that mark someone out as being f

I think Thanksgiving is mostly about belonging.

I was raised in a culture other than that of either of my parents or my nationality: what they call a Third Culture Kid. With that sort of profile, belonging is hard to come by. As a child, I sounded British but wasn‚Äôt; I didn‚Äôt get the overt cultural references and didn‚Äôt share the unspoken common understandings that mark someone out as being from the same tribe. I was indelibly other, and felt it, and knew it.

I‚Äôm thankful for my family for providing that sense of belonging: a space in my life that felt safe and was rich with those shared understandings. In the same way that some people are proud of the region they‚Äôre from or their religion or some other demarcation of sameness, I‚Äôm endlessly proud of my mother, my father, my sister, who each of them were and are as people, and who we all have been together. It‚Äôs not perfect or spotless ‚Äî I‚Äôve sometimes disappointed them in all sorts of ways, both small and catastrophic ‚Äî but it‚Äôs ours. I‚Äôm lucky. Not everyone has that sense of belonging; that safety. A feeling of home, not from a place or things or nationality, but from people.

I used to throw Thanksgiving dinners when I lived in Edinburgh. I think people were grateful for the meal, if a bit nonplussed about why I was holding such a big dinner party on a Thursday. I found a sense of temporary community there, over homemade tortillas sprawled over the kitchen table of our top-floor tenement flat, but never quite belonging.

In my life, I‚Äôve rarely been able to recreate that sense of belonging outside of our unit, and my aunts, uncles, and cousins. I‚Äôve learned that I mostly find a shared sense of belonging with people who also share some degree of outsiderness, whose identities don‚Äôt quite fit into cookie-cutter homogeneity.

These days, of course, I have a new belonging: to a tiny child for whom I‚Äôm safety, who curls up into my arms and sleeps, who I put food on the table for, and who comes to me for kisses when he‚Äôs hurt or feeling sad. I see my new role as extending my family forward, and helping to give him all the warmth, safety, and, yes, non-conformity I got from mine.

Thanksgiving, then, for me, is about families, whether born or adoptive or found, and gratitude for the people who create safety and warmth. I‚Äôm thankful for mine: the one I‚Äôm linked to by blood, and the people who I‚Äôve been lucky enough to call home, some of whom are overlapping.

This Thanksgiving I‚Äôm also thankful for the people who create that sense of belonging in the world: who seek to create bonds and build community, to try and forge belonging for everyone, rather than withdraw and isolate.

I‚Äôm thankful for the people who have to work so hard just to be themselves, to fight for their own identities, and for the people who see them as they are, not through the lens of outdated societal norms or inherited expectations. I‚Äôm thankful for people who want to include, and see inclusivity as a guiding value, not as a pejorative.

I‚Äôm thankful for the people who see suffering in places like Gaza and think, how can everyone belong and be safe, and not, these people had it coming, or this has nothing to do with me. I‚Äôm thankful for the people who see war and want it to end, not silently, but with their voices, on the streets.

I‚Äôm thankful for people who see the suffering of working people and choose to stand up for their rights and their well-being; for unions, for higher minimum wages, for protections, for laws and movements that give everybody a voice and a good life. I‚Äôm thankful for people who think, how can we improve and build a good life for everybody?

I‚Äôm thankful for the people who see every religion (and no religion) equally, and who push to ensure everybody has an equitable place.

I‚Äôm thankful for the people who see generational inequalities and want to right them, to halt cycles of harm so that future generations do not have to endure them.

I‚Äôm thankful for the people who see and act as if the world is one connected place, where every single person matters, regardless of where they are, what their background is, who they worship, or what their political leaders believe.

This Thanksgiving, I hold gratitude not only for my family and the belonging they‚Äôve given me but also for those who strive to build a world where everyone can feel at home.

Happy Thanksgiving to all of you. I hope you have belonging, and love, warmth, and safety.

18:11 • 20 days ago

@_Nat Zone

ÁèæÂú∞ÊôÇÈñì11Êúà28Êó•„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„ÅØÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£ÔºàeIDÔºâ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„Ç≥„Ç¢Ê©üËÉΩ„Å®Ë™çË®º„ÅÆË¶èÂâá„ÇíÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ‰∏ã„ÅßÊé°Êäû„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØ„ÄÅÂä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅåËá™ÂõΩ„ÅÆ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅ2026Âπ¥Êú´„Åæ„Åß„Å´„É™„É™„Éº„Çπ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÈáçË¶Å„Å™‰∏ÄÊ≠©„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ 4„Å§„ÅÆÂÆü‚Ä¶

ÁèæÂú∞ÊôÇÈñì11Êúà28Êó•„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÂßîÂì°‰ºö„ÅØÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£ÔºàeIDÔºâ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„Ç≥„Ç¢Ê©üËÉΩ„Å®Ë™çË®º„ÅÆË¶èÂâá„ÇíÊ¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ‰∏ã„ÅßÊé°Êäû„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØ„ÄÅÂä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅåËá™ÂõΩ„ÅÆ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅ2026Âπ¥Êú´„Åæ„Åß„Å´„É™„É™„Éº„Çπ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÈáçË¶Å„Å™‰∏ÄÊ≠©„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

4„Å§„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ÊñáÊõ∏„ÅÆ„ÇØ„É≠„Çπ„Éú„Éº„ÉÄ„ÉºÂà©Áî®„Å´ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„Éá„Éº„Çø„Éï„Ç©„Éº„Éû„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇÑ„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰ø°È†ºÊÄß„Å®„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÇíÁ¢∫‰øù„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÊé™ÁΩÆ„Å™„Å©„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆÊäÄË°ìÁöÑÊ©üËÉΩ„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÁµ±‰∏ÄÁöÑ„Å™Âü∫Ê∫ñ„ÄÅ‰ªïÊßò„ÄÅÊâãÈ†Ü„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÁµ±‰∏Ä„Åï„Çå„ÅüÂü∫Ê∫ñ„Å®‰ªïÊßò„ÇíË®≠ÂÆö„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅÂêÑÂä†ÁõüÂõΩ„ÅØ„ÄÅÂÄã‰∫∫„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å®„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„Çí‰øùË≠∑„Åó„Å™„Åå„Çâ„ÄÅEUÂÖ®‰Ωì„ÅßÁõ∏‰∫íÈÅãÁî®ÂèØËÉΩ„Åã„Å§Âèó„ÅëÂÖ•„Çå„Çâ„Çå„ÇãÊñπÊ≥ï„Åß„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÇíÈñãÁô∫„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅØ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà‰∏ä„Å´„É≠„Éº„Ç´„É´„Å´‰øùÂ≠ò„Åï„Çå„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÅØÂÖ±Êúâ„Åô„ÇãÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíÂà∂Âæ°„Åß„Åç„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆË®≠Ë®à„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„Éà„É©„ÉÉ„Ç≠„É≥„Ç∞„ÇÑ„Éó„É≠„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É™„É≥„Ç∞„ÅØ‰∏ÄÂàá„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åõ„Çì„ÄÇ„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅ„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„ÉÄ„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•„Éú„Éº„Éâ„ÅåÁµÑ„ÅøËæº„Åæ„Çå„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅÆÂÖ±ÊúâÊñπÊ≥ï„ÇÑÁõ∏ÊâãÂÖà„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶ÂÆåÂÖ®„Å™ÈÄèÊòéÊÄß„ÅåÁ¢∫‰øù„Åï„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

5„Å§ÁõÆ„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„ÅØ„ÄÅeID„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆË™çË®º„ÅÆ„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÂ†ÖÁâ¢„Å™„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ‰ªïÊßò„Å®ÊâãÈ†Ü„ÇíÂÆö„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£„Å®„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÅÆ„Éó„É©„Ç§„Éê„Ç∑„Éº„Åä„Çà„Å≥ÂÄã‰∫∫„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅÆ‰øùË≠∑„ÇíÁ¢∫‰øù„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Ê¨ßÂ∑û„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¢„Ç§„Éá„É≥„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éª„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅØ„ÄÅÂÄã‰∫∫„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÇÑ‰ºÅÊ•≠„ÅåÂõΩÂ¢É„ÇíË∂ä„Åà„Å¶ÂÖ¨ÂÖ±„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„ÇÑÊ∞ëÈñì„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Å´„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çª„Çπ„Åô„ÇãÈöõ„Å´„ÄÅÊôÆÈÅçÁöÑ„Åß‰ø°È†ºÊÄß„ÅåÈ´ò„ÅèÂÆâÂÖ®„Å™ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÅßË∫´ÂÖÉ„ÇíË®ºÊòé„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰ΩøÁî®ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÅÆ‰æã„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÅØ„ÄÅÈäÄË°åÂè£Â∫ß„ÅÆÈñãË®≠„ÄÅÂπ¥ÈΩ¢„ÅÆË®ºÊòé„ÄÅÂåªÁôÇÂá¶Êñπ„ÅÆÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÅËªä„ÅÆ„É¨„É≥„Çø„É´„ÄÅËà™Á©∫Âà∏„ÅÆË°®Á§∫„Å™„Å©„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

ÂÆüÊñΩË¶èÂâá„ÅØÂæåÊó•„ÄÅÊ¨ßÂ∑ûÈÄ£ÂêàÂÖ¨Â†±„Å´Êé≤Ëºâ„Åï„Çå„ÄÅ20Êó•Âæå„Å´Áô∫Âäπ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

(Âá∫ÊâÄ) https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/mex_24_6122

13:49 • 20 days ago

Wednesday, 27. November 2024

Wrench in the Gears

Working Notes On Ghayat al-Hakim (The Picatrix) and Possible Intersections Between Web3 and Mystical Islam

Because I need to head out to dig the last of my garden beds before frost sets in, I am making a rather fragmented placeholder post to hold links I recently shared with online colleagues. I‚Äôm going to use this as a reference for my future self, but perhaps others will also find it to [...]

Because I need to head out to dig the last of my garden beds before frost sets in, I am making a rather fragmented placeholder post to hold links I recently shared with online colleagues. I‚Äôm going to use this as a reference for my future self, but perhaps others will also find it to be of interest.

The notes that follow focus on two videos. The first is about math, symbolic representation, octopi, and chaos magic. The second presentation features mystical Islam and astral manipulation, which I sense may be related to Michael Levin and Richard A. Watson‚Äôs work linking ancient spirituality with electrical blueprints embedded in, or emerging from, the morphic field.

I am currently in alignment with Joseph Gonzalez‚Äôs analysis that posits consciousness as the base layer of quantum realism. His investigations have much to do with resonance, coherence, wave-making (and collapse) that take different forms. You can read his work here. I find Joseph‚Äôs assessment to be congruent with my ideas about John Wheeler‚Äôs participatory universe.

https://embed.kumu.io/d06861b7582610d232b4780f258858d4#untitled-map?s=bm9kZS1kcW1NRHo4cQ%3D%3D

The cymatics he discusses below overlap with my recent interest in Sufism. I am currently reading ‚ÄúThe Mysticism of Sound and Music: The Sufi Teaching of Hazrat Inyat Khan,‚Äù an Indian mystic whose teachings were quite important to the development of jazz.

https://bantamjoe.com/2024/11/11/cymatic-patterns-of-consciousness/ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lw9r7ZTsqWo

From my place on the elephant, these two talks, which are relatively short (clocking in at about a half-hour each), share interrelated themes. These themes intersect with my ‚Äúreality tunnel,‚Äù which has been consistently focused on Web3 spatial computing, blockchain governance, soul alchemy, social impact game mechanics through token engineering, and the Human Potential Movement.

The first video I found, because I regularly scan the updates on the Active Inference Institute‚Äôs youtube channel. The second, on the Ghayat-al-Haim, was sychronously inboxed to me by someone whose email address I don‚Äôt recognize as I was watching the first video. The two relate to my latest video about abductive thinking. That discussion was catalyzed by a friend sharing a David Snowden paper about navigating complex futures.

https://wrenchinthegears.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Dave-Snowden-Through-A-Glass-Darkly-A-Complex-Systems-Approach-To-Futures.pdf

Today, Stephers emailed me a fascinating PDF of a book on ‚Äúintuition pumps‚Äù that seems very much related to what I touched on in my video (yes, it‚Äôs that rhizomatic thinking again). I haven‚Äôt had the chance to do more than scan it, but the fact that Dennett has been based out of Tufts (where Levin is working) for forty years, combined with a jaw-dropping table of contents has bumped it to the top of my ‚Äúto-do list.‚Äù

https://wrenchinthegears.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Intution-Pumps-And-Other-Tools-For-Thinking-Daniel-Dennett.pdf

Below is the first video.

I got caught flat-footed when the presenter said he was a ‚Äúvoluntarily defrocked math professor,‚Äù who now identifies as an octopus and chaos magician. Of note ‚Äì John Clippinger based out of the MIT Media Lab and co-founder with Sandy Pentland of the Open Mustard Seed digital ID protocol, is the first listed board member of the Active Inference Institute.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p77yZJ0Bf38 https://embed.kumu.io/49c9f7eb178114bdde9bdd34fd4cb935#untitled-map?s=bm9kZS1GY21MN0hITQ%3D%3D https://www.activeinference.institute/board-of-directors

Note 1: In relation to the first video ‚Äì Could entertainment infrastructures like Netflix serve as a conceptual linguistic apparatus for orchestrating collective memetic interventions?

Note 2: First video, continued ‚Äì The origin of the word ‚Äúflick‚Äù (as in movies) comes from flicker ‚Äì relating to the lamps used in early movie projectors. Perhaps ‚ÄúNet‚Äù ‚ÄúFlix‚Äù is referencing a brief glimpse of Maya, Indra‚Äôs Net, quantum potential we each hold, and it is a matter of piecing together these flickers into a coherent ‚Äústory‚Äù (Boik‚Äôs CogNarr).

Note 3: The presenter describes himself as a chaos magician and references Ramsey Dukes (Link1, Link 2).

Note 4: In second video ‚Äì this academic paper by Saif on the science of intuition is of interest to me (Link)

https://www.academia.edu/97707286/Physiognomy_Science_of_Intuition

Note 5: Reference (click here) to rival Islamic legal systems associated with different religious schools of thought. I picture how this could relate to spatial computing and smart contracts and values embedded in smart environments ala Pask. Could competing religious texts become autopoetic regulators by managing social systems in a hidden manner? See the concept of Hadith.

Note 6: Reference (click here) to astral magic reminds me of Joseph‚Äôs work on quantum realism and consciousness.

Note 7: Saif mentions Charles Burnett‚Äôs work on magic. That featured podcast also did an interview (click here) with Brian Copenhaver, mentor in magic to Nicholas ‚ÄúTransformations of the Human‚Äù Berggruen. See map above.

Note 8: This part (click here) is about the ‚Äúsoul work‚Äù of the sage and reminds me of Soul Bound Tokens and James Hillman‚Äôs Alchemy of the Soul of the City (Dallas). See maps above.

Note 9: Saif mentions the Islamic idea of Hikmah, the actualization of the soul. Think ‚Äúmoral economy‚Äù in a faith-based, programmed, outside-in robotic environment ‚Äúoptimizing‚Äù some pre-determined human potential metrics in a ‚Äúwellness‚Äù economy. The ‚Äúgood deeds‚Äù part would be in alignment with LDS focus on good works and social impact, Sharia law, Tikkun Olam, and P3 megachurch ‚Äúcharity‚Äù work ala Peter Drucker. Note Drucker worked closely with Texas (blockchain) cable TV (programming) mogul Bob BUFORD to launch the Protestant Megachurch movement in the 1980s. Note for later ‚Äì Buford is the first name of the sheriff (seven-pointed star badge) in Smokey and the Bandit II impersonated by John Titus in a recent chat with CAF.

https://embed.kumu.io/acdb50e1d61494808102a5db701a598f#untitled-map?s=bm9kZS0wUFdPb3Q1WA%3D%3D

Note 10 ‚Äì Regarding Snowden taking a pilgrimage on the road to Compostela in Portugal and Henry Corbin‚Äôs idea of the pilgrim, soul work, and the ‚Äúemblematic city.‚Äù

https://thecynefin.co/pagoda/ https://www.amiscorbin.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/Corbin_en_1976_Emblematic_Cities.pdf

Note 11: Could there be a connection between astrology and the morphic field?  Per Saif (click here). My observation: I am starting to see astrology as being a story we tell to comprehend dynamic morphic fields / blueprints that may emerge from quantum consciousness and the ‚Äúrays‚Äù mentioned as routes of entanglement between multidimensional information spaces.

Note 12: Discussion of Hermetic magical objects including reference (click here) to ‚Äúvapors,‚Äù which has resonance here in Hot Springs. See the historic Vapors night club. In the past people who came to seek healing at the hot springs were said to be taking the vapors.

https://vaporslive.com/history/ https://vaporslive.com/history/

Note 13: Mentions that Aby Warburg had association with the book of magic (click here). See my post on Nam Shubs (mind viruses / memetics) including references to Bettina Warburg of the same family connected to ‚Äúvending machine‚Äù blockchain governance.

https://wrenchinthegears.com/2021/12/31/on-cyberpunk-sumeria-synagogues-and-vending-machine-government/

Note 14: Ok, so there are different reality tunnels. Some might center ‚ÄúBitcoin Billionaires.‚Äù Others might center ‚ÄúIntuition Pumps‚Äù and ‚ÄúBiofilm  Quorum Sensing.‚Äù Pause for a second. Get yourself situated on your Hegelian ‚Äúproblem-reaction-solution‚Äù anchor point. Are you there? Are you comfortable? Ok. Now, imagine what different ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù might await you depending on the tunnel you step into. Maybe you are on team CAF.  She offers a story that is certainly familiar and appealing to her devoted subscribers. In that story, you can be the aggrieved victim of ‚Äúthe cabal.‚Äù Perhaps you have been carefully groomed for that role of angry Plebeian investor. Alternatively, you could step into the field as an active participant, take a shot at managing your own consciousness, and try to figure out what is going on ‚Äúunder the the hood‚Äù in the field of quantum realism. Remember, YOU get to CHOOSE. I encourage you to choose wisely. Though, if you make a misstep, you can always choose again. I‚Äôm not here to tell you that one future is preferable over another. Maybe they are all happening at once? Maybe there really is no single, verifiable ‚Äúreality.‚Äù

But ask yourself how is it that these folks plan to fight the ‚Äúcontrol grid‚Äù but never speak of digital community currency, the noosphere, gamified token engineering, Charles Eistenstein‚Äôs buddy Sep Kamvar and their Celo project? Why does John Titus break into a ‚ÄúSmokey‚Äù (see Nicotinic Aceytlecholine Receptors) and the Bandit II act here pretending to be Sheriff (pretty close to Benartzi‚Äôs Shareitt) Buford (see Drucker sidekick above) to ‚Äúmeditate‚Äù (non-local consciousness access) because of a heart (coherent torus field for quantum manifestation) condition? Might it have something to do with Charles‚Äôs friend Galila and her past work on Bancor and Lev (heart tokens)? Wouldn‚Äôt it make sense for CAF to have some position on ReFi and what‚Äôs underway in Great Barrington with the E.F. Schumacher Center? She‚Äôs no dummy. She‚Äôs carved out a place on the game board where she can keep lots of people very occupied in her ‚Äúreality tunnel.‚Äù Of course the same could be said for me, but my crowd is ever so much smaller and in that way I suppose any potential damage I could do would be relatively inconsequential in the long run. Such a puzzle, and so many pieces to play with. By the way, can anyone tell me what Sheriff Buford‚Äôs ‚ÄúHema Gauge‚Äù is? This was the sequel, so II (twin) with CAF sporting a magenta orchid (human flourishing, anyone?) behind her, and John with those paired (Cleve Backster primary perception h/t perhaps?) houseplants before a tripartite (soul trinity) window. Blessings and gratitude to all for this fascinating ride!

Furthermore, these credentials are essential foundations for identification in jurisdictions that have no national identity scheme. In those cases, they have a policy model defining levels of assurance built upon inputs such as these credentials above: „Åï„Çâ„Å´„ÄÅ„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆ„ÇØ„É¨„Éá„É≥„Ç∑„É£„É´„ÅØ„ÄÅÂõΩÊ∞ëID„ÅÆ„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„É†„ÇíÊåÅ„Åü„Å™„ÅÑÁÆ°ËΩÑÂå∫Âüü„Å´„Åä„Åë„ÇãË≠òÂà•„ÅÆ„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ‰∏çÂèØÊ¨†„Å™Âü∫Áõ§„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åù„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™Â†¥Âêà„ÄÅ„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆË™çË®º„Å™„Å©„ÅÆÂÖ•ÂäõÊÉÖÂ†±„Å´Âü∫„Å•„ÅÑ„Å¶‰øùË®º„É¨„Éô„É´„ÇíÂÆöÁæ©„Åô„Çã„Éù„É™„Ç∑„Éº„É¢„Éá„É´„ÅåÁî®ÊÑè„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Åæ„Åï„Å´‰∏ä„Å´Êõ∏„ÅÑ„ÅüMartin„ÅÆË©±„Å®„ÇÇÁπã„Åå„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÂõΩ„ÅåÁî®ÊÑè„Åó„ÅüÊú¨‰∫∫Á¢∫Ë™çÊõ∏È°ûÔºàIdentity DocumentÔºâ„ÅåÔºà‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÔºâÊ©üËÉΩ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Å™„ÅÑÂõΩÔºàÂÆü„ÅØ„Ç¢„É°„É™„Ç´„ÇÇ„Åù„ÅÜ„Åß„Åô„Çà„Å≠Ôºâ„Åß„ÇÇ„Ç™„É≥„É©„Ç§„É≥„Éª„Ç™„Éï„É©„Ç§„É≥Âïè„Çè„ÅöË∫´ÂÖÉÁ¢∫Ë™ç„Çí„Åô„Çã„Éã„Éº„Ç∫„ÅØÂΩìÁÑ∂Â≠òÂú®„Åô„Çã„Çè„Åë„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åù„ÅÆÈöõ„Å´ÂõΩÊ∞ëID‰ª•Â§ñ„ÅÆ„ÇØ„É¨„Éá„É≥„Ç∑„É£„É´„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„Å¶Ë∫´ÂÖÉÁ¢∫Ë™ç„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„ÅÆ„ÅØ„Ç§„É≥„ÇØ„É´„Éº„Ç∏„Éß„É≥„ÅÆË¶≥ÁÇπ„Åß„ÇÇÈùûÂ∏∏„Å´ÈáçË¶Å„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó„ÄÅ„Åù„ÅÆÈöõ„Å´„Åò„ÇÉ„ÅÇ„Åù„ÅÆ„Éâ„Ç≠„É•„É°„É≥„Éà„ÅÆÁô∫Ë°å„Å´„ÅØ„Å©„ÅÆ„Åè„Çâ„ÅÑ„ÅÆ‰øùË®º„É¨„Éô„É´„ÅåÊãÖ‰øù„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅãÔºü„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜË©±„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ


„Åì„ÅÆ‰øùË®º„É¨„Éô„É´„ÇíÁÆóÂÆö„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ„É¢„Éá„É´„ÇíOIX„ÅßÊèê‰æõ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åù„Åó„Å¶Ê¨°„ÅÆ„Çπ„ÉÜ„ÉÉ„Éó„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÇÇË™û„Çâ„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

As next steps, the Trust Frameworks working group, in partnership with OIX, intends to:

Publish its findings Conduct more analysis in new jurisdictions Build a comparison tool Propose policy criteria for metadata exchange

Ê¨°„ÅÆ„Çπ„ÉÜ„ÉÉ„Éó„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ‰ΩúÊ•≠ÈÉ®‰ºö„ÅØ„ÄÅOIX„Å®„ÅÆ„Éë„Éº„Éà„Éä„Éº„Ç∑„ÉÉ„Éó„ÅÆ„ÇÇ„Å®„ÄÅ‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆ„Åì„Å®„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ‰∫àÂÆö„Åß„ÅÇ„ÇãÔºö

Ë™øÊüªÁµêÊûú„ÅÆÂÖ¨Ë°® Êñ∞„Åü„Å™ÁÆ°ËΩÑÂå∫Âüü„Å´„Åä„Åë„Çã„Åï„Çâ„Å™„ÇãÂàÜÊûê„ÅÆÂÆüÊñΩ ÊØîËºÉ„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÅÆÊßãÁØâ „É°„Çø„Éá„Éº„Çø‰∫§Êèõ„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„Éù„É™„Ç∑„ÉºÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÅÆÊèêÊ°à 

„Åì„Çå„ÅØÂÖàÊó•„ÅÆÊù±‰∫¨„Çµ„Éü„ÉÉ„Éà„Åß„ÇÇË©±„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åó„Åü„Åå„ÄÅÊó•Êú¨„ÅÆDS500„ÇÇÂê´„ÇÅ„Å¶„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„ÅØ‰∏ÄÂÆö„ÅÆÈÄ≤Ë°å„ÇíË¶ã„Åõ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åó„Åü„Å≠„ÄÇ„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅ‰ªäÂæå„ÅØÂõΩ„ÅåÊèê‰æõ„Åô„Çã„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ„Åø„Å™„Çâ„ÅöÈ†òÂüü„Åî„Å®„Å´„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„ÇíÈÄ≤„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Åì„Å®„Å´„Å™„Çã„Å®ÊÄù„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÊú¨ÂΩì„ÅÆÊÑèÂë≥„ÅßÂΩπ„Å´Á´ã„Å§„ÅÆ„ÅØÈ†òÂüüÂçò‰Ωç„ÅßÊÑèÂë≥„ÅÆ„ÅÇ„Çã„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Åå„Å™„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åã„Çâ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åù„ÅÜ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åì„Åì„ÅßÁõÆ„ÇíÂºï„Åè„ÅÆ„ÅåÊúÄÂæå„Å´Êåô„Åí„Çâ„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„É°„Çø„Éá„Éº„Çø‰∫§Êèõ„Å´„Åä„Åë„Çã„Éù„É™„Ç∑„ÉºÂü∫Ê∫ñ„ÅÆË©±„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØ‰Ωï„ÅãÔºü„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„Åì„Çì„Å™Âõ≥„ÅåÊèêÁ§∫„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ


Ë¶Å„Åô„Çã„Å´‰∏≠Â§ÆÈõÜÊ®©Âûã„Å†„Çç„ÅÜ„ÅåÂàÜÊï£Âûã„Å†„Çç„ÅÜ„Åå„Éï„Çß„Éá„É¨„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Âûã„Å†„Çç„ÅÜ„Åå„ÄÅ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Çí„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´„ÅØÂΩìË©≤„ÅÆ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„É°„Çø„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí‰∫§Êèõ„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™‰ªïÊéõ„Åë„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„Å´„Å™„Çã„Å£„Å¶„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ

„Åì„Çì„Å™ÂΩ¢„ÅßËß£Ë™¨„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Whatever the mechanism, the Trust Framework mapping and analysis forms the basis for metadata exchange requirements. This is useful for jurisdictions now looking to create their own Trust Framework and in order to facilitate negotiations and, eventually, the technologies that will enable dynamic interactions on a transaction-by-transaction basis (for example: ‚ÄúSmart Wallets‚Äù). Interestingly, in mapping all of the actors and rule-sets that would be required in such an ecosystem, the analysis shows that much of it actually has been defined in the eIDAS 2.0 framework.

‰ªïÁµÑ„Åø„Åå‰Ωï„Åß„ÅÇ„Çå„ÄÅ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆ„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Å®ÂàÜÊûê„ÅØ„É°„Çø„Éá„Éº„Çø‰∫§ÊèõË¶Å‰ª∂„ÅÆÂü∫Á§é„ÇíÂΩ¢Êàê„Åô„Çã„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„ÅØÁèæÂú®„ÄÅÁã¨Ëá™„ÅÆ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„Çà„ÅÜ„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„ÇãÂõΩ„ÉªÂú∞Âüü„Åå„ÄÅ‰∫§Ê∏â„ÇÑ„ÄÅÊúÄÁµÇÁöÑ„Å´„ÅØÂèñÂºï„Åî„Å®„ÅÆ„ÉÄ„Ç§„Éä„Éü„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Å™„ÇÑ„ÇäÂèñ„Çä„ÇíÂèØËÉΩ„Å´„Åô„ÇãÊäÄË°ìÔºà‰æã„Åà„Å∞„Äå„Çπ„Éû„Éº„Éà„Ç¶„Ç©„É¨„ÉÉ„Éà„ÄçÔºâ„Çí‰øÉÈÄ≤„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´ÊúâÁî®„Åß„ÅÇ„Çã„ÄÇËààÂë≥Ê∑±„ÅÑ„Åì„Å®„Å´„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™„Ç®„Ç≥„Ç∑„Çπ„ÉÜ„É†„ÅßÂøÖË¶Å„Å®„Åï„Çå„Çã„Åô„Åπ„Å¶„ÅÆ„Ç¢„ÇØ„Çø„Éº„Å®„É´„Éº„É´„Çª„ÉÉ„Éà„Çí„Éû„ÉÉ„Éî„É≥„Ç∞„Åô„Çã„Å®„ÄÅ„Åù„ÅÆÂ§ö„Åè„ÅåeIDAS 2.0„ÅÆ„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅßÂÆöÁæ©„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åå„Çè„Åã„Çã„ÄÇ


 

eIDAS2.0„Å´„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÇíÈáç„Å≠Âêà„Çè„Åõ„Çã„Å®„Åì„Çì„Å™ÊÑü„Åò„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇIdentity Assurance„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„É´„Éº„É´„ÄÅCredential„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãTrust„É´„Éº„É´„ÄÅWallet„ÇÑ„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´ID„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„Ç¢„Ç´„Ç¶„É≥„ÉàTrust„É´„Éº„É´„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Çπ„Ç±„Éº„ÇπÂçò‰Ωç„ÅÆTrust„É´„Éº„É´„Å´ÂàÜÈ°û„Åï„Çå„ÄÅ„Åì„Çå„ÅØWallet„É¢„Éá„É´‰ª•Â§ñ„Å∏„ÅÆÈÅ©Áî®„ÇÇ„Åß„Åç„Çã„ÄÅ„ÅÑ„Çè„ÇÜ„Çã„É°„Çø„Å™„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Å®„Å™„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÊï¥ÁêÜ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åì„ÅÆ„É¢„Éá„É´„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„Éô„É´„É™„É≥„Åß„ÅØ„Ç∞„É´„Éº„Éó„Å´Âà•„Çå„Å¶Ë≠∞Ë´ñ„ÅåË°å„Çè„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ


„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÇíÊØîËºÉ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÅØ‰Ωï„Çí„Åô„Åπ„Åç„Åã„ÄÅ„Å©„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´Â±ïÈñã„Åï„Çå„Çã„Åπ„Åç„Åã„ÄÅË™∞„Åå‰Ωø„ÅÜ„Åπ„Åç„ÇÇ„ÅÆ„Å™„ÅÆ„Åã„ÄÅ„Å™„Å©Ë≠∞Ë´ñ„ÅØÂ§öÂ≤ê„Å´Ê∏°„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ


ÁµêÊûú„Å®„Åó„Å¶‰ºöÂ†¥„Åã„Çâ„ÅØ„Åì„Çå„Çâ„ÅÆÊÑèË¶ã„ÅåÈõÜ„Åæ„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åæ„Å®„ÇÅ„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅØÈùûÂ∏∏„Å´Èõ£„Åó„ÅÑ„Å®ÊÄù„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„Åå„ÄÅ‰ªäÂæå‰∏ÄÊ≠©„Åö„Å§ÈõÜÁ¥Ñ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åë„Çã„Å®ËâØ„ÅÑ„Å®ÊÄù„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰ªäÂæå„ÅØTrust Framework Work Stream„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Éà„É©„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØÊØîËºÉ„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÄÅ„Å©„ÅÆ„É´„Éº„É´„ÅåÂøÖË¶Å„Å™„ÅÆ„Åã„ÄÅ„Å™„Å©„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë≠∞Ë´ñ„ÇíÁ∂ôÁ∂ö„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åè„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åì„ÅÆÂæå„ÄÅNick„ÅåÂÆüÈöõ„Å´ÊØîËºÉ„Çí„Åó„Å¶„Åø„Å¶„Å©„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™„ÇÆ„É£„ÉÉ„Éó„Åå„ÅÇ„Å£„Åü„ÅÆ„ÅãÔºü„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„Åæ„Å®„ÇÅ„Å¶Ë©±„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„Åå„ÄÅ„Åù„Çå„ÅØ„Åæ„ÅüÊîπ„ÇÅ„Å¶„ÄÇ

Ben Werdm√ºller

For Love of God, Make Your Own Website

[Gita Jackson at Aftermath] I love a good treatise in favor of the indie web: "Unfortunately, this is what all of the internet is right now: social media, owned by large corporations that make changes to them to limit or suppress your speech, in order to make themselves more attractive to advertisers or just pursue their owners‚Äô ends. Even the best Twitter alternatives, like

[Gita Jackson at Aftermath]

I love a good treatise in favor of the indie web:

"Unfortunately, this is what all of the internet is right now: social media, owned by large corporations that make changes to them to limit or suppress your speech, in order to make themselves more attractive to advertisers or just pursue their owners‚Äô ends. Even the best Twitter alternatives, like Bluesky, aren‚Äôt immune to any of this‚Äîthe more you centralize onto one single website, the more power that website has over you and what you post there. More than just moving to another website, we need more websites."

Almost every single advance in my career, and many of the good things that have happened in my personal life, have come from writing on my own website over the years. It's both liberating and empowering to have your own platform - and anyone can build one.

And this is also true:

"‚ÄúWe were already long overdue for a return to websites we control, rather than feeds manipulated by tech oligarchs,‚Äù Molly White from Web3 Is Going Great! told me. ‚ÄúNow that they‚Äôve made it clear how eager they are to help usher in authoritarianism, I think it will only become more painfully clear how important sovereign websites are to protecting information and free expression.‚Äù"

Want to start blogging? I made you a guide. Want to put up a website of any kind but don't know where to start? Show up at a Homebrew Website Club and say hello. There are so many ways to start, and so many ways to be online. Go get started.

#Indieweb

[Link]

18:15 • 21 days ago

Talking Identity

Broadening the Definition of Identity Practitioner

One of the wonderful, yet also daunting, aspects of being in the Identity industry is realizing just how far-reaching and all-encompassing its scope and boundaries are. It‚Äôs why we need more than just technologists and standards wonks engaged in driving the future of this industry. I‚Äôve been on stage at Identiverse and other conferences for [‚Ä¶]

One of the wonderful, yet also daunting, aspects of being in the Identity industry is realizing just how far-reaching and all-encompassing its scope and boundaries are. It‚Äôs why we need more than just technologists and standards wonks engaged in driving the future of this industry. I‚Äôve been on stage at Identiverse and other conferences for many years challenging the Identirati to bring in people from other fields like User Experience Research, Law, Privacy, and more.

This is the challenge that the Digital Identity Advancement Foundation has taken on. You can check out how they are doing this on their website, via the Kim Cameron Award and the Vittorio Bertocci Award. Thanks to Arynn Crow, I had the chance to spend some time chatting with the 2024 Kim Cameron award winner, legal scholar Grace Klutke, at Authenticate 2024. We talked (in my usual rambling sort of way) about ethics in Identity, and the broader impact on human rights, inclusion, and access (in the human and not the technical Authorization sense). You can read her reflection on her experience at the conference here.

Oh, and support DIAF if you can. They‚Äôre doing good, and necessary, work! If DIAF continues to bring smart, talented, and motivated individuals like her from other fields into our industry, then we‚Äôll be doing it right.

15:49 • 21 days ago

Tuesday, 26. November 2024

IdM Laboratory

„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíRP„Å®„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„Éó„É≠„Éê„Ç§„ÉÄ„ÅßÂêåÊúü„Åô„ÇãË©±

„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ Â∞ë„ÅóÂâç„Å´Google„ÅÆ„Åà„Éº„Åò„Åï„Çì„ÅåPasskey„ÅÆSingal API„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë®ò‰∫ã„ÇíÊõ∏„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ https://developer.chrome.com/blog/passkeys-signal-api?hl=ja Ë¶Å„Åô„Çã„Å´„ÄÅRPÂÅ¥„Å´ÁôªÈå≤Ê∏à„Åø„ÅÆ„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„Å®„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂ÂÅ¥„Å´Â≠òÂú®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„Åå„Åö„Çå„Å™„ÅÑ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´Signal„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„Å¶Ê§úÁü•„ÄúÂêåÊúü„Çí„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜË©±„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ „Çà„Åè„ÅÇ„Çã„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„Å†„Å®RPÂÅ¥„Å´„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÇíÁôªÈå≤„Åó„Åü„ÅÆ„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÅÑ„Çì„Å†„Åë„Å©„ÄÅ„Éñ„É©„Ç¶„Ç∂ÂÅ¥„Åß„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÇíÂâäÈô§„Åó„Å¶„Åó„Åæ„Å£„Åü„ÄÅ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØ„Åù„ÅÆÈÄÜ„Çí„Åó„Å¶„Åó„Åæ„Å£„Åü„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÂ†¥Âêà„Å´Ë™çË®ºÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅåÈÄÅ„Çå„Å™„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÈÄÅ„Å£„Å¶„ÇÇÁôªÈå≤ÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅåÂâäÈô§„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë™çË®º„Åß„Åç„Å™„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÁä∂ÊÖã„ÇíÈò≤„Åé„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÅ„Å£„Å¶„Åì„Å®„Åã„Å®„ÄÇ „Åü„Å†„ÄÅSignal API„Åß„ÅØ„Åì„ÅÆ„Ç∑„Éä„É™„Ç™„ÅÆ„ÅÜ„Å°„ÅÆÂâçËÄÖ„Å´„ÅØÂØæÂøú„Åß„Åç„Åö„ÄÅÂæåËÄÖ
„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ„ÄÅÂØåÂ£´Ê¶Æ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ
Â∞ë„ÅóÂâç„Å´Google„ÅÆ„Åà„Éº„Åò„Åï„Çì„ÅåPasskey„ÅÆSingal API„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë®ò‰∫ã„ÇíÊõ∏„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ https://developer.chrome.com/blog/passkeys-signal-api?hl=ja

Ë¶Å„Åô„Çã„Å´„ÄÅRPÂÅ¥„Å´ÁôªÈå≤Ê∏à„Åø„ÅÆ„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„Å®„ÄÅ„É¶„Éº„Ç∂ÂÅ¥„Å´Â≠òÂú®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„Åå„Åö„Çå„Å™„ÅÑ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„Å´Signal„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„Å¶Ê§úÁü•„ÄúÂêåÊúü„Çí„Åß„Åç„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜË©±„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ
„Çà„Åè„ÅÇ„Çã„Ç±„Éº„Çπ„Å†„Å®RPÂÅ¥„Å´„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÇíÁôªÈå≤„Åó„Åü„ÅÆ„ÅØ„ÅÑ„ÅÑ„Çì„Å†„Åë„Å©„ÄÅ„Éñ„É©„Ç¶„Ç∂ÂÅ¥„Åß„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„ÇíÂâäÈô§„Åó„Å¶„Åó„Åæ„Å£„Åü„ÄÅ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØ„Åù„ÅÆÈÄÜ„Çí„Åó„Å¶„Åó„Åæ„Å£„Åü„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÂ†¥Âêà„Å´Ë™çË®ºÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅåÈÄÅ„Çå„Å™„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÈÄÅ„Å£„Å¶„ÇÇÁôªÈå≤ÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅåÂâäÈô§„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Å¶Ë™çË®º„Åß„Åç„Å™„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÁä∂ÊÖã„ÇíÈò≤„Åé„Åæ„Åó„Çá„ÅÜ„ÄÅ„Å£„Å¶„Åì„Å®„Åã„Å®„ÄÇ
„Åü„Å†„ÄÅSignal API„Åß„ÅØ„Åì„ÅÆ„Ç∑„Éä„É™„Ç™„ÅÆ„ÅÜ„Å°„ÅÆÂâçËÄÖ„Å´„ÅØÂØæÂøú„Åß„Åç„Åö„ÄÅÂæåËÄÖ„Å∏„ÅÆÂØæÂøú„ÅÆ„Åø„Å®„Å™„Çã„Åø„Åü„ÅÑ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Å§„Åæ„Çä„ÄÅRPÂÅ¥„ÅåSignal API„Å´ÂØæÂøú„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çå„Å∞„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„Éó„É≠„Éê„Ç§„ÉÄ„Å∏ÈÄöÁü•„ÅØ„Åß„Åç„Çã„Åë„Å©„ÄÅ„Éë„Çπ„Ç≠„Éº„Éó„É≠„Éê„Ç§„ÉÄÂÅ¥„ÅßÂâäÈô§„Åó„ÅüÊÉÖÂ†±„ÅØRP„Å∏„ÅØÈÄöÁü•„Åï„Çå„Å™„ÅÑ„ÄÅ„Å£„Å¶„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„Å≠„ÄÇ
‰ªïÊßò„ÅØW3C„ÅÆGithub„ÅßÂÖ¨Èñã„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅßÊôÇÈñì„ÇíË¶ã„Å¶Ë™≠„Çì„Åß„Åø„Çà„ÅÜ„Å®ÊÄù„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÔºà„Åª„ÅºÔºëÂπ¥Ââç„Å´‰Ωú„Å£„Åü„ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÁî®„ÅÆÂÆüË£Ö„Å∏„ÇÇÂèçÊò†„Åó„Åü„ÅÑ„Åß„Åô„Å≠Ôºâ https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#sctn-signal-methods
22:30 • 21 days ago

The Pragmatic Engineer

IDEs with GenAI features that Software Engineers love

AI-first IDEs like Cursor, WindSurf, Zed and others, are challenging Visual Studio Code‚Äôs dominance. What‚Äôs making devs switch over?

Hi, this is Gergely with an issue of the Pragmatic Engineer Newsletter. In every issue, I cover challenges at Big Tech and startups through the lens of engineering managers and senior engineers. To get articles like this in your inbox, every week, subscribe:

Subscribe now

In this issue, we cover:

Which IDEs do software engineers love, and why? Software engineers shared their favorite integrated development environments (IDEs) on social media, and the most-mentioned one by a comfortable margin was Cursor. WindSurf and Zed also seem to be getting traction at the expense of Visual Studio, and JetBrains.

Industry pulse. The Model Context Protocol by Anthropic; Bluesky getting close to Threads; Automattic crosses another ethical red line; Amazon resignations could be up again, and more.

1. Which IDEs do software engineers love, and why?

It‚Äôs been nearly 6 months since our research into which AI tools software engineers use, in the mini-series, AI tooling for software engineers: reality check. At the time, the most popular tools were ChatGPT for LLMs, and GitHub copilot for IDE-integrated tooling. Then this summer, I saw the Cursor IDE becoming popular around when Anthropic‚Äôs Sonnet 3.5 model was released, which has superior code generation compared to ChatGPT. Cursor started using that improved model.

To get a sense of how preferences of developers might have shifted, I asked:

‚ÄúIf you're a dev: what is your favorite coding editor with GenAI features (that help your work)? What's a standout thing about it?‚Äù

I posted on Bluesky, on X and on Threads, and received 155 often detailed responses. We look into it below.

As with all research, we have no affiliation with any of the vendors mentioned, and were not paid to mention them. More in our ethics policy.

Data source

Most responses come from Bluesky and X, and it‚Äôs noticeable that Bluesky seems to have consistently more developers active on it recently, compared to X. We cover more on Bluesky‚Äôs popularity spike in the Industry Pulse section below.

Of 155 responses, 77 were posted on Bluesky, 62 on X and 16 on Threads

This data is likely to be biased towards early tech adopters and non-enterprise users, as I posted on social media, and self-selecting software engineers active on those sites who are likely to be up-to-date on new tools, and willing to adopt them. There were more replies from developers at smaller companies like startups or smaller scaleups, and very few respondents from larger companies.

Data from early adopters tends to indicate where innovation is within tooling. However, many tools which early adopters use never go mainstream, often because status-quo vendors adapt their tooling for customers before new competitors can take too many customers. In this case, ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù IDEs are Visual Studio, Visual Studio Code, and JetBrains IDEs. Their competitors intent on disrupting the status quo are the new IDE startups which have launched within the past couple of years.

Favorite IDEs IDE that devs name as their favorites

Most popular by number of mentions:

Cursor. An AI-first code editor, rapidly gaining popularity.

Visual Studio Code with GitHub Copilot. Most respondents using Microsoft‚Äôs free IDE reported using GitHub Copilot within this IDE. Visual Studio Code supports many extensions, including the likes of Supermaven and Cline (see below).

A JetBrains IDE with GitHub Copilot. JetBrains makes language-specific IDEs. Those mentioned were IntelliJ, PyCharm, PHPStorm, and RubyMind.

Windsurf Editor. An ‚Äúagentic IDE‚Äù released by Codeium just two weeks ago, which is attracting users fast.

Zed. A next-generation code editor designed for collaboration with AI.

Neovim with Copilot. Neovim is a Vim-based text editor supporting plenty of extensions, including GitHub Copilot. 

Supermaven: not an IDE, but an AI completion utility that works in IDEs like VS Code, or JetBrains IDEs. It was acquired last week by Cursor, which looks a smart acquisition.

Aider: a terminal-based pair programming assistant, not an IDE. Those using Aider have an IDE on the side, parallel with AIder.

Cline: an extension, not an IDE. It‚Äôs an autonomous coding agent integrating into IDEs 

IDEs in the ‚Äòother‚Äô slice with a couple of mentions:

Cody by Sourcegraph: a coding assistant integrating into IDEs like Visual Studio and JetBrains IDEs.

v0 by Vercel: a text-to-design interface specialized for frontend projects generation (React and NextJS projects)

Replit AI Agent: an IDE to work with an AI agent to generate code

Bolt.new by Stackblitz: create full-stack web apps from a single prompt

Neovim Avante: a Neovim plugin designed to emulate the behaviour of the Cursor AI IDE

Eclipse Theia: an open source IDE, which recently shipped AI support

Augment Code: an AI platform designed for teams

Continue.dev: an open source AI assistant

Pear: an open source AI editor

Pricing: are all tools heavily subsidized?

All the tools utilize AI models for generating code, and these operations cost money to execute! Even so, several tools are free ‚Äì with a limit on usage; but even paid-for prices feel very reasonable for professional developer tools.

Free tools (for basic usage):

Zed (free for signed-in users during the initial launch period, thanks to a partnership with Anthropic)

Cursor (2-week trial)

Windsurf (individual free plan)

v0 by Vercel (individual free plan)

Replit AI Agent (starter plan)

Cody (Free plan)

Bolt.new (2M free tokens during the Thanksgiving period)

Jetbrains AI (7-day trial)

Tools costing $10-20/month for professional-grade capabilities:

Cody ($9/month, Pro plan)

GitHub Copilot ($10/month, Individual plan)

JetBrains AI ($10/month, Pro plan)

Replit AI Agent ($15/month, Core plan)

Stackblitz ($18/month, Pro plan)

Cursor ($20/month, Pro plan)

v0 by Vercel ($20/month)

Claude ($18/month, Pro plan) or ChatGPT ($20/month, Plus plan): necessary to subscribe for tools like Aider, Cline or Eclipse Theia, or when using your preferred model with some tools

Team and enterprise prices are more expensive across all tools; usually around double the individual cost. Several add enterprise features like enforcing privacy, admin dashboards, centralized billing, etc.

The only tool costing above $20/month is Augment Code, which charges $60/month, per developer. Assuming there‚Äôs a productivity boost from using this tool, even this lofty price tag would be a bargain.

As such, these prices feel heavily subsidized by vendors, who may be offering capabilities at a loss. Giving away GenAI functionality for free or at a low price, means vendors must fund the infrastructure powering these models from sources other than revenue.

There is a reasonable expectation that over time, the cost of generating tokens will decrease. However, right now, any engineer making heavy usage of code generation is likely getting good value for money, in terms of the compute required for code generation on larger codebases.

With that, let‚Äôs look at the most popular IDE startups, and why engineers prefer them over established tools like VS Code.

Cursor

The AI IDE startup was founded in 2022, and released the first version of their IDE in March 2023. My sense is that the popularity of Cursor started increasing in around July 2024, when they added support for the Sonnet 3.5 model and made it the default.

Here‚Äôs some reasons why Cursor is the favorite IDE of developer Roman Tsegelskyi, as shared by him:

‚ÄúCursor [is my favorite] even after trying the competitors. Small things standout:

1. Cursor rules, and ability to save context

2. Fast apply compared to competitors

3. Composer

Overall, I feel that Cursor also produces better results for me. However, I can't fully understand why!‚Äù

Composer is a feature that several engineers mentioned as the main reason they use Cursor. It‚Äôs an AI agent-like feature that can work across several files, following instructions to implement functionality described in the prompt. Here‚Äôs an example from iOS developer, Thomas Ricouard, instructing Composer to extract key views on a screen of an iOS app into their independent views, and the tool doing the task:

Composer is on the right of the IDE, and works across several files. Source: Thomas Ricouard on X

Other useful features for developers:

Better code generation. Cursor choosing to use Sonnet 3.5 as their default model seems to have been a smart move. GitHub Copliot seemed to respond three weeks ago by ditching OpenAI exclusivity, and allowing developers to also use Anthrophic‚Äôs newest LLM model for code generation.

Speedy. A common take was that Cursor felt faster compared to other tools.

Chat. Several developers like the dedicated chat window, where you can interact with an LLM without leaving the development environment.

Easy in-line editing. Easy to select several lines, then add instructions to the AI on how to edit them

Familiarity. As a Visual Studio Code fork, the user interface is familiar to all VS Code 

Switching models. This reveals how different LLMs work, and developers can choose the one that fits best.

There are developers who used Cursor for a while, then moved on. The most common complaint I saw was that Cursor gives too many suggestions, and too often; to the point of feeling over-intrusive.

Windsurf

This is a recently-released AI code editor, built by Codeium. I sense a similar buzz about it as when Cursor came out, but now Cursor is the one being compared . Windsurf focuses on further improving the collaboration flow with GenAI, and has an interface which makes it a lot easier to follow what the AI is doing.

Windsurf makes it easier to follow what the AI does. Look right to inspect each small diff. Source: Wes Bos on X

Techies said Windsurf is even more helpful when debugging, that it helps keep people in the coding loop, and proactively offers refactoring of messy codebases.

Cascade is one of Windsurf‚Äôs ‚Äúkiller‚Äù features. Similarly to Compose by Cursor, Cascade is an agentic chatbot to collaborate with across multiple files. It has a ‚Äúwrite code‚Äù and a ‚Äúchat‚Äù mode. It can also run terminal commands.

Here‚Äôs a comparison between Cursor and Windsurf by former product manager Amul Badjatya, who uses both for coding:

‚ÄúI've used the Windsurf for 30+ hours and Cursor for 150+ hours in last 8 weeks (premium subscription of both)

The Cascade workflow of Windsurf is superior to the Compose workflow of Cursor, with better indexing (+ code context). Cursor is really bad at it, while Windsurf is just so good, especially when a codebase is evolving fast.

Windsurf Cascade can run terminal commands, but Cursor Compose cannot. This is important because copy-pasting stuff from the terminal no longer breaks your flow.

Cursor‚Äôs Claude gets ‚Äútired‚Äù really quickly, just 30-60 minutes into coding. Meanwhile, Windsurf‚Äôs Claude is far more consistent in quality during the first few hours. It‚Äôs necessary to restart Cursor multiple times to keep the AI features responsive.

Cursor has a @web tag which helps you assimilate the latest information online, Windsurf does not. 

I can never update Markdown files (.md files) on Cursor Compose. They are somehow always half-updated in the file, half updated in the chat. I see similar problems when using other models: instead of modifying files, they reply in chat.

I am using Cursor right now for non-code research work due to @ web feature. My code-related work is driven primarily on Windsurf. I‚Äôm waiting for code indexing to get better on cursor.

Both tools are far ahead of Copilot or other plugins I've used. I really like both of them.‚Äù

It‚Äôs rare to see a new IDE be so popular, even with early adopters. I reached out to the Windsurf team for more details about the development of their innovative tool. Their response:

How big is the team at Windsurf?

‚ÄòThe engineering team as a whole is upwards of 50 people. Product engineering, research, and infrastructure all had to come together to create the Windsurf experience ‚Äì especially Cascade.‚Äô

How did the team come up with Cascade?

‚ÄòWe started with the existing paradigms of AI usage:

Copilots are great because of their collaborativeness with the developer; the human is always in the loop. That being said, to keep the human in the loop, copilots are generally confined to short-scoped tasks. 

Agents are great because the AI can independently iterate to complete much larger tasks. The tradeoff is that you lose the collaborative aspect, which is why we haven‚Äôt seen an agentic IDE (yet). An IDE would be overkill. 

‚ÄòBoth copilots and agents are powerful, but have generally been seen as complementary because their strengths and weaknesses are indeed complementary.

‚ÄòThe idea of Cascade really stemmed from the question: ‚Äúwhat if the AI had the best of both worlds, what if the AI was capable of being both collaborative and independent? This quality is one aspect of what makes humans special.

‚ÄòWe knew that for this to work, we would need to have a series of purpose-built models, the latency would have to be very low for these agents to feel ‚Äúcollaborative.‚Äù and we‚Äôd have to find the right way to combine knowledge sources, tool calls, and realtime tracking of developer behavior. These were research problems that had to all be solved to make possible this new paradigm, which we have dubbed as Flows. Cascade is the flow evolution of chat, but it is just the beginning.‚Äô

Which LLM does Cascade use?

‚ÄòWe use a set of many models. Some are third-party models like Anthropic's or OpenAI's for some of the long-context reasoning steps, while we have other models for our LLM-based retrieval, fast application of code changes, and more.‚Äô

Did you use Windsurf to build Windsurf?

‚ÄòYes! Many core features we've built into Windsurf were built with Windsurf! While forking VS Code, Windsurf was a huge accelerant for helping developers navigate through the new codebase quickly and make changes.‚Äô

Can you give an example of a large codebase that uses Windsurf, and how large it is?

‚ÄòHenry Shi, the cofounder of Super.com (a $100MM/yr business) used it on their large codebase, which has millions of lines of code in the monorepo, supporting their frontend across 10+ domains.‚Äô

Zed

This IDE was publicly released in March 2023, the same month as Cursor launched. The tool is built by a core team of 14 developers, and is one of the only AI tools to offer free, unlimited AI completion for registered users ‚Äì thanks to a collaboration with Anthropic. This feature will surely become a paid product, in the future.

Here‚Äôs why Zed is the favorite editor of software engineer and founder, Siddhart Jha:

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to provide specific files to the ai context window, choose models, use completions from copilot/supermaven.

I like that the ai features are unobtrusive and stay out of the way until needed.‚Äù

Other reasons devs prefer Zed:

Very good Vim mode: for engineers preferring this kind of user interface. For devs who love Vim, Zed seems to be a popular choice of editor.

Fast. A frequent compliment is how snappy both the editor and LLM responses are. The Zed team implemented prompt caching for Anthropic models to get a speed boost.

Keymaps. The editor can be configured to use the key mappings of the IDEs you‚Äôre used to; be it JetBrains, Sublime Text, VSCode, or another. This makes it particularly easy to switch for those used to JetBrains IDEs.

Several models. The editor nicely integrates with several LLMs.

Zed configs: these files can be easily shared. Here‚Äôs an example file

Notes on Visual Studio Code and JetBrains IDEs

Engineers sticking with Visual Studio Code or JetBrains seem to mostly use code autocomplete. The big ‚Äúwow‚Äù moments of Cursor and Windsurf are their multi-file editing and agentic capabilities. Devs hooked on this functionality don‚Äôt seem to want to go back to the more limited experience offered by GitHub Copilot, and most AI integrations with Visual Studio Code and JetBrains IDEs.

There are plugins like Cline that work across several files, but the user experience is more limited and confined to being an extension, in contrast to how Cursor and Windsurf build a new type of IDE around these features.

Where is JetBrains AI? An interesting observation about JetBrains is that most devs using its IDEs also use GitHub Copilot as the LLM, even though JetBrains offers its own JetBrains AI. This service is at exactly the same price point as Copilot, so it would be expected that devs on JetBrains IDEs use the provided LLM tool. But it doesn‚Äôt seem to be happening. Feedback shared by engineers is that JetBrains AI is not as good as the competition: specifically, it doesn‚Äôt ingest code as efficiently as others.

Given that AI assistants continuously improve, as and when JetBrains does so then it might be able to bring back customers already using their IDEs.

Is this an IDE revolution?

Many IDEs have launched and gained momentum in the span of 18 months, and the innovation isn‚Äôt over yet.

Expect even more startups to launch new AI-powered IDEs. There are several AI startups that have raised hundreds of millions of dollars and are yet to release a public-facing product, including:

Magic.dev: the stealth generative AI startup raised $320M in funding in August, with ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt also investing. The company has not yet released a product, but is working on something new.

Cognition AI: the developers behind the ‚ÄúAI developer‚Äù Devin raised $175M also in August, and have yet to release a product publicly.

Don‚Äôt count out Microsoft any time. I was surprised that Cursor is far more popular than Visual Studio Code and GitHub Copilot because Microsoft has a strong brand, superior distribution, and the tech giant seemed to out-execute GenAI startups in 2021-2024 with GitHub Copilot.

GitHub even previewed GitHub Workflows in March, which was supposed to be the evolution of Copilot, and would have brought agentic behavior to Visual Studio. But something seems to have happened since then. GitHub got ‚Äústuck‚Äù with what felt like an outdated LLM model (GPT 4.0), and did not respond to functionality like Composer by Cursor and Cascade by Windsurf.

At the same time, Microsoft is still in an enviable strategic position in this AI-powered IDE competition:

Nearly all ‚Äúwinning‚Äù IDEs are built on top of Visual Studio Code. Both Cursor and Windsurf are Visual Studio Forks. This means that Microsoft can integrate innovations created by those forks quickly enough into Visual Studio Code and Visual Studio. The development effort for this takes months, not years.

The GitHub team remains nimble, and will surely respond. When Microsoft acquired GitHub, it did not integrate the organization into Microsoft, but has left it operating relatively independently. This means the GitHub team can move quickly when needed. Already, GitHub Copilot added support for more advanced LLM models like Sonnet 3.5.

Microsoft‚Äôs distribution advantage is not going anywhere. No other large company can sell enterprise tools to larger companies like Microsoft. For it to remain the vendor offering the most-used AI-powered IDEs, it doesn‚Äôt need to be the best on the market because large companies with Microsoft enterprise deals will convert much easier to Visual Studio and GitHub Copilot, rather than to a startup‚Äôs tool.

Zed is a promising direction, proving it‚Äôs still possible to start from scratch. Across the popular IDEs, Zed is the only non-Visual Studio Code fork. The IDE is built from scratch, using Rust. Zed defies what seems to be the conventional wisdom these days: that to build an IDE that gets adoption, it‚Äôs unwise to not fork Visual Studio Code.

AI-powered IDEs are firmly at the ‚Äúbooming innovation‚Äù stage. There are so many AI-powered IDEs because there‚Äôs an opportunity to capture a large part of the developer market; this is a market worth billions of dollars in annual revenue, with tech professionals willing to pay for advanced tools that improve their output.

It‚Äôs clear that Microsoft is being out-innovated by startups like Cursor, Windsurf, Zed, and others with plentiful investment in becoming the winner of an AI-powered IDE battle to be the next JetBrains of the AI era. Meanwhile, JetBrains is the #2 IDE tools maker, globally, behind Microsoft, with 16 million developers using its products; so it‚Äôs already a pretty big target to shoot at.

Good luck to all teams building innovative IDEs. As a software engineer, why not try some of the new challenger products; they may help increase productivity and make day-to-day work easier!

2. Industry pulse 10 and 11 December to be huge launch days?

Read more

17:23 • 22 days ago

Monday, 25. November 2024

IdM Laboratory
